author: ryanleeschneider
content:
I have a question about: https://barnabe.substack.com/p/pos-ethereum-reorg I want to make sure I understand something correctly.

The above article is about a 7 block beacon chain reorg back in May, so obviously pre-merge.  In this case, the beacon chain actually gets shorter, after the reorg, correct?

Basically the chain goes from slots: `... 74, 75, 76, 77, 78, 79, 80, 81`
To the new chain: `... 74, 82, 83`

This seems to have interesting implications for the EL side.  If we assume that each of these slots were filled, and that slot 74 contained EL block 1000, then the chain reorgs like so:

From: `1000 (74), 1001 (75), 1002 (76), 1003 (77), 1004 (78), 1005 (79), 1006 (80), 1007 (81)`
To `1000 (74), 1001 (82), 1002 (83)`

Which is to say that the canonical EL chain gets shorter.  Am I reading this correctly that this is possible?

author: potuz
content:
The reorg is from 75--81 to 74,82,.... 
So if 73 had 999 (following your example) then 74 and 75 will both have 1000.

author: potuz
content: So the chain will reorg from 1000(75)...1006(81) to 1000(74), 1001(82)

author: djrtwo
content: Yes. And such a reorg to a shorter chain is possible in PoW as well

author: djrtwo
content: In both pow and Ethereum PoS, a chain being longer does not necessarily mean it has more weight

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Yes but in PoW the total difficulty field is up-to-date and available via the JSONRPC api, so if you had two nodes on different chains you could compare their total difficulty to see which one is further along.  That functionality isn't really available post-merge, since the block attestation counts aren't available via JSONRPC.

author: potuz
content: There is a debug endpoint for the forkchoice store. It's not standardized yet but it contains that information in all implementations. However, knowing vote count can be very misleading
